verb.description: Take the trouble to do something.
examples: scientists rarely bother with such niceties
the driver didn't bother to ask why

verb.description: (of a circumstance or event) worry, disturb, or upset (someone)
examples: secrecy is an issue that bothers journalists
it bothered me that I hadn't done anything
he saved me the bother of having to come up with a speech
it may seem like too much bother to cook just for yourself

phrases: they couldn't be bothered to look it up
But, I really can't be bothered to put in the effort to finish it.
However, I still find myself reaching for it if I have five minutes to kill or can't be bothered to load up anything else.
Throughout my conversation, she gave such dull and unwilling answers, as if she can't be bothered to talk to me.
When you can't be bothered to write but you've got loads of stuff spilling out of your head, you can still share it all with this cool tool.
origin: Late 17th century (as a noun in the dialect sense noise, chatter): of Anglo-Irish origin; probably related to Irish bodhaire noise, bodhraim deafen, annoy. The verb (originally dialect) meant confuse with noise in the early 18th century.
